response.answer_text: Americans: Senator Phil Gramm (myopia)Senator Barry Goldwater (moderate myopia and astigmatism)Senator Harrison H. “Jack” Schmitt (astigmatism — had a prescription for corrective lenses when he was an astronaut at NASA, by the way, and was one of three Apollo crewmembers to bring a set of corrective lenses with him to the Moon)President Ronald Reagan (high myopia, refraction not available, however his uncorrected 20/800 acuity kept him from being assigned to combat duty during WW2)President Harry Truman (highly farsighted, +8.00 dioptres, and was rejected from West Point for this reason)President Theodore Roosevelt (high myopia, an estimated —8.00 dioptres) . First US President to allow himself to be photographed wearing his spectacles.President Woodrow Wilson (myopia)President Franklin Delano Roosevelt (high myopia)President Abraham Lincoln (moderately farsighted)President George Washington (mildly farsighted, presbyopic — actually apologised for donning his spectacles during his Farewell Address)Israeli: Menachem BeginIranian: Shah Mohammed Reza PahlaviSoviet: Leon TrotskyKatangese: Moise TschombeJapanese: Generalissimo Hideki TojoEmporer HirohitoNB: the actual, full list would be much longer. Keep in mind that just because someone in the public eye doesn’t normally appear wearing spectacles, it doesn’t mean that he doesn’t need them. Many public figures — especially entertainers — choose to wear contact lenses. E.g.: Ronald Reagan regularly wore contact lenses.

Err ... what?!  Both the majority and the minority leaders in your senate wear glasses! (Harry Reid and Mitch McConnell)    Currently, at the cabinet level, you have Jason Furman, the Chairperson of the Council of Economic Advisers and the Secretary of the Treasury, Jack Lew who wear glasses.  Then, you have Al Franken from MN, probably the most popular liberal currently in the Congress.   Last of all, a certain DICK CHENEY staring right at ya!
